advisors.name: Mary Tran
advisors.bio: Mary Tran has been serving clients as a financial advisor at Charles Schwab for over 25 years. Specializing in tax and estate planning, Mary has a proven track record of helping clients navigate complex financial situations and achieve their long-term goals.

advisors.name: John Washington
advisors.bio: John Washington has over 30 years of experience in the financial industry. As a financial advisor at Fidelity, John specializes in creating and managing investment strategies and portfolios tailored to each client's unique financial goals and risk tolerance.

advisors.name: Carlos Rodriguez
advisors.bio: Carlos Rodriguez is a seasoned financial advisor with over 15 years of experience at Wells Fargo Advisors. Carlos specializes in comprehensive financial planning and risk management, helping clients create a secure financial future.

advisors.name: Jennifer Lee
advisors.bio: Jennifer Lee has been a financial advisor at Raymond James for over 35 years. She specializes in retirement planning, wealth management, and tax planning, helping clients realize their financial dreams while minimizing tax liabilities.

heroDescription: Finding a financial advisor in Houston, Texas can be a strategic move to navigate the city's dynamic and diverse economy.
landscapeDescription: According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis (2023), Houston's economy is robust, with a strong presence in energy, healthcare, and manufacturing sectors. Major employers include ExxonMobil, Memorial Hermann Health System, and The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center.
uniqueNeeds: With a diverse economy and high cost of living, Houstonians may need tailored financial strategies.

sections.title: Economic Growth
sections.description: According to Bureau of Economic Analysis (2023), Houston's GDP was $525 billion, indicating a growth rate of 2.5% from the previous year. This growth was largely driven by the energy sector, healthcare, and manufacturing industries.

sections.title: Wealth Demographics
sections.description: According to U.S. Census Bureau (2023), the median household income in Houston is $67,462. The city has a significant proportion of high-income households, with 15% earning over $150,000 annually. The wealth distribution indicates a growing middle class, with 35% of households earning between $50,000 and $100,000.

sections.title: Advisor Specializations
sections.description: Based on Bureau of Labor Statistics (2024), the healthcare sector is one of the largest employers in Houston, suggesting a need for financial advisors specializing in healthcare professionals. Additionally, the significant presence of the energy sector indicates a demand for advisors with expertise in energy-related investments.

sections.title: Cost of Living
sections.description: According to Bureau of Labor Statistics (2024), the Consumer Price Index for Houston rose by 2.3% over the previous year, slightly above the national average. The cost of healthcare and housing were significant contributors to this increase.

sections.title: Real Estate Market
sections.description: According to Zillow (2024), the median home value in Houston is $245,000, a 4% increase from the previous year. The real estate market is expected to remain stable, with a projected growth rate of 3% over the next year.

sections.title: Business Environment
sections.description: According to Fortune 500 (2024), Houston is home to 22 Fortune 500 companies, including Phillips 66, Sysco, and ConocoPhillips. The city's business-friendly environment, coupled with its strategic location and access to global markets, continues to attract a diverse range of businesses.
